content.description: Start all the way into the cave. Using burly undercling body tension, pull to get established, and go slight right to the jug. From there, go left to get established on the face, and top out. There is a variation (V4 also?, the ending is easier, but you still have to do the V4 sit start move) - follow the crack to the corner, and lay it back for the corner topout.
content.protection: 2 pads will cover everything. It can be done with one pad.
content.location: It's on the overhang on the left side of the crag that forms almost a cave.

content.description: Start almost lying down with your hands matched on small, low rail. Bump up to a good jug, then top out straight up using pockets and the finishing jug. This is short but fun.
content.location: Start to the right of Undercling Overhang.

content.description: This is the best line at the crag. Start at the very right side toe of the crag. Traverse left (north) using the middle holds. The crux comes at near the end as the holds peters out and one has to swing out for feet to the left of the final crack. Get established to the left of the crack (the final block of the crag), and casually top out.
content.protection: I put pads at the end where the crux is.
content.location: Traversing the whole crag, start on the right side right at the gully, and the rock is broken slab.

content.description: As the name implies, 2/3 Traverse avoids the crux of The Full Traverse for a much more mellow finger workout. Start on the right end of the crag.   Traverse left into a corner before the overhanging block, and top out.
content.location: Start at the right side of the crag by the gully.

content.description: North Side has a small overhang and nice traverse problems. Much chalk has been seen from Mud Road on this block over the years.
